4.18.text: This is a map of someone’s brain,

7.18.text: showing  roughly which areas respond when they hear different words.

14.04.text: For example, there’s a small area in the middle frontal gyrus

17.64.text: that reliably responds to hearing the word ‘top’.

22.78.text: But it’s not just one word, one location.

27.22.text: A single word can activate a whole range of different brain regions.

32.62.text: So, we find the word ‘top’ in a bit of brain that seems to respond

36.54.text: to words associated with clothing and appearances.

41.16.text: But also, here, with numbers and measurements.

44.94.text: And here, with buildings and places.

48.58.text: We usually think of language as being restricted

51.16.text: to certain sections like the temporal lobe.

54.06.text: So researchers were surprised to find activity all across the brain,

61.24.text: The map was made by scientists at the University of California, Berkely.

65.26.text: They put volunteers in an MRI scanner

67.80.text: and had them listen to stories for 2 hours.

72.54.text:
and she pulls out a pack of matches
that had been laundered at least once…

77.20.text: By monitoring blood flow to different parts of the brain

80.32.text: they worked out which places were responding to the meaning of the words:

86.20.text: They found that different bits of the brain

88.36.text: responded to different kinds of words and concepts.

92.36.text:
And they could group them into rough
categories,

95.32.text: shown here by the different colours.

100.03.text: were most activated by words to do with numbers,

105.80.text: Here, in the right temporoparietal junction,

108.48.text: this speck of brain, just a few millimetres across,

111.18.text:
was found to respond to words like
‘wife’, ‘mother’, ‘pregnant’ and ‘family’.

116.74.text: And this bit just next door responds to some of the same social words,

123.42.text: but also words to do with places and people

129.48.text: Generally, the concepts represented in each brain region

132.72.text: relate to other functions that scientists already know about;

136.92.text: so, words to do with how things look, such as ‘stripes’,

140.26.text: are likely to be found near the visual cortex.

143.43.text: And although each individual’s map is different,

147.74.text: it’s clear that different people have the same kinds of concepts

151.04.text: in the same kinds of places.

155.33.text:
This is the first time we’ve been able to
map

157.61.text: the semantic systems of the brain in such detail –

161.28.text: discovering that words are grouped by meaning,

164.16.text: and revealing just how complicated, and widespread,

167.30.text: the word maps in our heads really are.

171.40.text: And, the brain map is available online for anyone to explore.
